results.title: Camila [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Maria Luisa Bemberg, Lita Stantic, GEA Cinematografica S R L and Impala S.A. (SP)
results.brief_description: Set in a small Argentinean town in 1847, Camila (played by Susu Pecoraro) is the daughter of a wealthy diplomat growing up amid a bucolic and privileged, albeit confined, existence. Camila grows up to be a headstrong woman who clashes frequently with her conservative family. When she confesses the conflicted thoughts and disturbing dreams that concern her to Ladislao Gutierez (Imanol Arias), a Jesuit priest, the two soon enter into a torrid affair. Defying convention, her tyrannical father and overwhelming opposition from the Church and society, the doomed lovers are driven into exile where they live together anonymously. Despite their passionate union they continue to suffer torment and guilt as a result of their choices. As a political critique, “Camila” lays bare the power that the conservative, repressive Rosas government had over the people of Argentina at that time although the narrative skirts around the complexities of these issues in favour of the lovers’ plight. Based on a true story, which was reputedly suppressed by authorities due to its controversial subject matter, this historical melodrama pays great attention to period detail, serving as a fascinating portrait of Argentinean culture, in particular religious traditions and societal mores. Where it lacks perhaps is in its traditional depiction of the lovers’ passion, manifested in several bodice-ripping sequences. Cast also includes Hector Alterio, Elena Tasisto, Carlos Munoz and Hector Pellegrini. Academy Award nominee for Best Foreign Language Film.

results.title: The Nugget
results.creator_credit: Bill Bennett, Jennifer Cluff, b j films, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Macquarie Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Lotto, Wookie and Sue are three working class mates whose favourite pastime is to frolic in the outback on a futile hunt for gold, dodging the protestations of their spouses. One day however luck befalls the hapless trio when they happen upon a giant nugget of gold, making them instantly rich. Avarice soon takes over and former rock-solid friendships are torn asunder by rivalries and petty disagreements. Bill Bennett (Kiss or Kill, Spider and Rose) borrows from the set-up of John Huston’s “The Treasure of the Sierra Madre” (1948) but inverts the drama in favour of slapstick comedy, trading on Aussie movie cliches (redneck attitudes, colloquial banter, ockerism, boozing, mateship) familiar themes from such comedies as “The Castle”, “Welcome to Woop, Woop”, “Muriel’s wedding” and even “They’re a weird mob” to create an allegorical fable about the perils of wealth cast in a fun, lightweight, albeit highly predictable, manner.

results.title: Never been kissed [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Raja Gosnell, Nancy Juvonen, Sandy Isaac, Bushwood Pictures, Flower Films and Fox 2000 Pictures
results.brief_description: In this romantic comedy Drew Barrymore plays Josie Geller, a nerdy self conscious (and at times self-loathing) twenty-five year old who harbours dreams of being swept off her feet by a prince, and falling in love for keeps. In reality she is perennially single and works for a newspaper as a copy editor whilst fostering ambitions to be a reporter. Part of Josie’s dream is realised when she is sent on an undercover assignment - back to high school. Unfortunately for Josie this means a return to the lion’s den - throughout her adolescence Josie was mocked mercilessly and once undercover she soon finds herself drawn back into the nerdy circles in which she is most comfortable. But when her editor demands that she joins the cool group Josie must transform herself or lose the assignment. Much of the humour in this film is quite black - the flashbacks (as well as those scenes in the present) when Josie is humiliated, are quite excruciating to watch. But the many sly intentions of the script are undermined by saccharine overtones that swamp the film. Barrymore however displays a deft talent for comedy, essentially carrying the film, playing a very sympathetic and quite believable teen and young adult.

results.title: Temptation of a monk = You seng [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Clara Law, Jill Bilcock, Teddy Robin Kwan and Tedpoly Films
results.brief_description: General Shi (Wu Hsin-kuo) is a loyal servant to heir apparent Prince Yuan-ji in the Chinese Tang Dynasty period. Fraternal jealousy is rampant amongst the sons in contention for the throne and Shi is offered the opportunity of a bloodless coup by a rival general: order his troops not to resist and no one will be hurt. The general reneges on his word and a bloody, trancelike battle ensues which sees the majority of Shi’s army, and the Prince, slaughtered. Shi, opposed to the new regime flees to a Buddhist shrine for refuge, and to secretly plot revenge with his comrades against those who turned against his leader. Another disastrous battle ensues in which he loses the Princess (Joan Chen) who has fallen in love with him and pursued him, as well as more men. Devastated he seeks redemption in a shrine, shaving heads of monks in the region, pondering his future, and being tempted by a widower (also played by Joan Chen) who visits the shrine seeking burial for her husband. Shot in an atmospheric blue hue, the plot of Clara Law’s film is at times hard to fathom, however it’s easy to savour the epic proportions of the film, the mesmerising battle scenes, and witness the restrained performance of the two leads as they manage to imbue their scenes with sensuality and passion. Cast also includes: Zhang Fengyui, Michael Lee.

results.title: I can't sleep = J'ai pas sommeil [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Claire Denis, Bruno Pesery, Agora, Arena Films, Films de Mindif and France 3 Cinema
results.brief_description: Based on the true story of Theirry Paulin who, with his male lover, murdered over twenty elderly women in the 1980s, “I can’t sleep” is a serial killer movie that avoids cliches of the genre, preferring fresh insights via its allusive Parisian protagonists. Daiga is an aspiring Lithuanian actress, who arrives in Paris expecting work but finds few opportunities open to her; Theo is a musician and carpenter from Martinique, estranged from the French mother of his young child, who longs to return to his family and homeland; Camille, his brother, is a beautiful drag queen and part time prostitute, joylessly making his way in the gay scene. Around these dynamics unfurls a series of heartless murders of elderly women. Characters grapple with urban dislocation and social isolation whilst recognising their enduring status as outsiders and limited possibilities. Whilst Denis may have intended to draw links between society’s treatment of those operating outside of the mainstream (immigrants, transvestites, homosexuals) and the consequences of intolerance for difference, generally this film raised the ire of viewers, many of whom interpreted these thematic links with murder as homophobic and racist. Cast includes Yekaterina Golubeva, Richard Courcet, Line Renaud, Beatrice Dalle and Alex Descas. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Ghost world [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Terry Zwigoff, John Malkovich, Lianne Halfon, Russell Smith, Granada Film Productions, Jersey Shore Films and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Terry Zwigoff followed up the unexpected success of “Crumb” (a startlingly heart-felt documentary on American comic book artist Robert Crumb) with “Ghost world” an adaptation of the popular comic novel by Daniel Clowes. Addressing the vagaries of suburban dysfunction, two misanthropic best friends graduate from High School, eager to explore new possibilities. Initially this equates to hanging out in dreadful 1950s retro diners, reading the personals and mocking the entire world. For Enid (Thora Birch), her identity is closely bound with aesthetics - her constantly changing outfits reflect her turmoil and eternal dissatisfaction. Becky (Scarlett Johansson), more conventionally pretty and able to attract male attention, has a singular goal - to move out with Enid into their own flat. But Enid, uncertain where her desires lie, defers making decisions, frustrating and isolating Becky. After initially humiliating avid record collector Seymour (Steve Buscemi) Enid is drawn to his eclectic interests and, recognising a kindred spirit, determines to find him a girlfriend. Unrelenting deadpan delivery confirms the melancholic tone of the film but dilutes the emotional content contained within a wry and savvy script. Whilst the characters’ physical surrounds are well captured (with some sumptuously shot interiors), the emotional core that drives Enid, and especially Becky is not. Ultimately “Ghost world” is a bittersweet comedy about transition and a journey toward the responsibilities, dilemmas and disappointments of adulthood.

results.title: Irreversible [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Gaspar Noe, Christophe Rossignon, 120 Films and Studio Canal
results.brief_description: Gaspar Noe’s “Irreversible” made its notorious debut at the 2002 Cannes film festival where it provoked extreme reactions from audiences. Subsequently it has been dubbed as the film with the most walkouts. Noe’s previous feature, “I stand alone” was considered at the time as an uncompromising and shocking film which presented a bleak and nihilistic view of humanity. Noe even included a foreboding warning to viewers to exit the cinema before its shocking climax, a claim that was no mere cheap effect. With “Irreversible” (which includes a brief cameo from the lead character of “I stand alone”) Noe has upped the ante to an intense degree, making this one of the more distressing films you are likely to experience. Taking the very well used genre of the revenge film as a starting point, Noe defies expectations and delivers a remarkable aural and visual assault on the senses. Using mainly improvised dialogue, a disorientating camera style and depicting the film’s events backwards, “Irreversible” goes from an intense act of violence, to a horrendous rape (which plays out in excruciating real time) and finally to a quiet contemplative moment. The film’s peaceful coda leaves a bitter and devastating aftertaste as we are left to ponder the film’s final words, ‘time destroys everything’. Please note: contains scenes of violence which may disturb some viewers, and depicts explicit sexual relationships. Cast includes: Albert Dupontel, Jo Prestia.

Noe’s previous feature, “I stand alone” was considered at the time as an uncompromising and shocking film which presented a bleak and nihilistic view of humanity. Noe even included a foreboding warning to viewers to exit the cinema before its shocking climax, a claim that was no mere cheap effect. With “Irreversible” (which includes a brief cameo from the lead character of “I stand alone”) Noe has upped the ante to an intense degree, making this one of the more distressing films you are likely to experience. Taking the very well used genre of the revenge film as a starting point, Noe defies expectations and delivers a remarkable aural and visual assault on the senses. Using mainly improvised dialogue, a disorientating camera style and depicting the film’s events backwards, “Irreversible” goes from an intense act of violence, to a horrendous rape (which plays out in excruciating real time) and finally to a quiet contemplative moment. The film’s peaceful coda leaves a bitter and devastating aftertaste as we are left to ponder the film’s final words, ‘time destroys everything’. Please note: contains scenes of violence which may disturb some viewers, and depicts explicit sexual relationships. Cast includes: Albert Dupontel, Jo Prestia.

results.title: Trouble every day [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Claire Denis, Georges Benayoun, Jean-Michel Rey, Philippe Liegeois, Arte France, Canal+ and Rezo Films
results.brief_description: Claire Denis’ “Trouble every day” is a hard to categorize genre film which seductively mixes up vampire mythology with cannibalism to explore the darker side of sexuality, fidelity and desire. The film follows parallel narratives which eventually converge, opening on a initially erotically charged heterosexual coupling which ends with the brutal murder of the male. The woman (played with mute ferocity by Beatrice Dalle), naked and covered in blood and gore is later discovered by her resigned husband (Alex Descas) who disposes of the mangled body, takes his wife home and ties her to their bed. Meanwhile an American doctor (Vincent Gallo) and his newlywed wife arrive in France for their honeymoon. Unbeknown to the young bride her husband has come to Paris with a darker agenda in mind. What begins to emerge is that the doctor and the murderess from the start of the film share a rare pathology that becomes shockingly apparent as the film plays out. Denis deliberately keeps the story opaque, instead relying heavily on mood created through the mournful and lush soundtrack by the Tindersticks and the evocative imagery, lensed by Denis’s regular cinematographer Agnes Godard. What emerges is a mysterious and compelling experience that doesn’t shy away from the more corporeal aspects of the story. Cast includes: Tricia Vessey, Florence Loiret, Nicolas Duvauchelle.

results.title: I am trying to break your heart: a film about Wilco
results.creator_credit: Sam Jones, Peter Abraham, Cowboy Pictures, Experience Music Project, Fusionfilms and Plexifilm
results.brief_description: In 2000 New York based rock band Wilco embarked upon the recording of their fifth studio album. With money from their record label, the band decided to self-produce “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot” - their most collaborative effort to date. Filmmaker Sam Jones recorded the process in what would prove an eventful year for the band, marked by frustration with the recording, personality clashes and issues with label executives. The film focuses chiefly on lead singer and songwriter Jeff Tweedy, a man driven by the urge to create, write and produce music who is at times perplexed by the vagaries of the music industry and the demands placed upon him as the face of Wilco. Shooting on 16mm, in black and white, with a hand-held camera, Jones creates a document that apes the successful look and feel of “Don’t look back” (1967) D. A. Pennebaker’s legendary examination of Bob Dylan on tour and in the spotlight at a crucial time of his career. Whilst Jones’ work cannot claim the same iconic status, his documentary is also an intimate, personal view of an artist at odds with the current traits of the American music business, with his fellow musicians and at times, with himself. Features footage of live performances, studio work and interviews with Wilco and various colleagues.

results.title: Josie and the pussycats [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Deborah Kaplan, Harry Elfont, Chuck Grimes, Marc Platt, Tony De Rosa-Grund, Tracey E. Edmonds, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Riverdale Productions and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the Archie comic book series, this teen flick is an exuberant adaptation of the characters of Josie, Valerie and Melody who form a rock group and are catapulted to stardom overnight after being discovered by a talent scout. Unbeknownst to the girls however, the label they have signed with, MegaRecords, run by Fiona (Parker Posey, revelling in the role of arch-villainess), insert subaural messages into the music that brainwashes teenagers into buying an array of products, from shoes to deodorant. When the label pushes Josie as the main artist, diminishing the roles of Val and Mel, the girls’ friendship is threatened. This film successfully satirises teenage marketing, consumerism, product placement, all-boy bands, manufactured pop and teen movies but undermines its credibility by gratifying the teen wish-fulfillment fantasy. The gaudy palette is utilised to great effect from the costumes of the band to the ever-changing sets; and the self-reflexive pop references flow thick and fast throughout the script that oscillates between all-knowing cleverness and straight up pandering to mainstream culture. Ultimately the film cannot decide which side of the fence it sits on but remains an amusing, fun distraction. Cast includes Rachael Leigh Cook, Tara Reid, Rosario Dawson, Alan Cumming and Gabriel Mann.
